title: CTRL0000916111 - Transcribed Interview of Michael Pompeo, (Aug. 9, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 12:00 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
, SENIOR COUNSELOR TO THE VICE CHAIR
For the COMMITTEE ON HOUSE ADMINISTRATION:
This is a transcribed interview of former Secretary of State Michael Pompeo
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
Secretary Pompeo, if you could please state your full name and spell your last
My name is Michael Richard Pompeo.
I see you're represented by counsel, Mr. Burck.
Bill, if you could also introduce yourself and spell your last name for the reporter.
My name is William Burck, B-u-r-c-k.
And we represent Secretary Michael Pompeo.
and I'm the chief investigative counsel for the select
them to introduce themselves and spell their names as well.
Several lawyers from the committee staff are with me today, and I'll ask
I'm the senior counsel to the
investigative counsel for the select committee.
who's a professional staff member, is
I don't know if we have any members present.
So, Secretary Pompeo, this will be a staff-led interview.
present decide to join, they may choose to ask questions, and I will try to let you know
and let Mr. Burck know if they join.
Ms. Lofgren and Mrs. Murphy, two members of our committee, are joining
I believe Ms. Lofgren is here.
There's also an official reporter who's transcribing the interview.
until each of my questions is complete before you begin your response, and I will try to
wait until your response is complete before asking the next question.
The reporter cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head.
important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
We ask that you just provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
If the question isn't clear, then just ask for clarification.
And if you don't know the
And then, although this interview is not under oath, I want to remind you -- and
this is not a Pompeo-specific admonition, it's something we tell everybody -- that it is
unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
Do you have any question about that or any of the other rules or guidelines that
And again, logistically, if you just need a break or
want to discuss anything with your attorney, just let us know.
clear for the record -- or actually, first, Bill, do you have a few things you wanted to put on
the record before I start questions?
I just wanted to confirm, I think, a couple of conversations I've had with you,_
and maybe other members of the staff.
As you all know, we've not been provided any documents in connection with this
not aware of any documents in your possession that reference or were sent to -- or I
shouldn't say reference, but were sent to or received or sent by Secretary Pompeo, nor
We've not done a search for documents.
My understanding is that we're not aware of and you're
We don't have ready access to State
Mr. Pompeo has gotten access to his calendar by the State Department in
connection with a book he's writing about his time as Secretary of State, but he has not,
nor have I, searched that for anything relating to January 6th.
And, again, sitting here today, Secretary Pompeo is not aware of any documents
or any information that would be relevant to the inquiry that he has in his possession.
So, just by necessity, he will be operating purely off of memory, and the memory
is now 18-plus months old, so he's going to do his best to answer your questions.
obviously understands, he'll answer the questions honestly, but, again, there will be
passage of time, as well as, again, he's purely working off of his best memories at this
So that's really all I had to stay.
I see that the vice chair, Ms. Cheney, has now joined.
So, Secretary Pompeo, I just want to make clear that you are here today
voluntarily, not pursuant to a subpoena or any legal process.
And are you familiar with the letter that was sent to your counsel
just yesterday by the current White House counsel's office indicating that, given the
magnitude of the issues evaluated by the select committee, that it would not be, in
President Biden's view, appropriate to assert any executive privilege over your testimony
I have not read the letter.
scope of the waiver provided by the White House, by President Biden, for this interview.
My counsel briefed me on the contents and the
And do you have any questions or concerns about that?
Let's talk a little bit about just your professional background.
with what you're doing now and maybe walk us back to West Point.
I'm now engaged in various business activities since my time leaving the
Also continuing to do work on behalf of
political candidates for the Republican Party.
And then spending more time with my
That's the three ways I'm occupying myself these days.
Before that, I was America's 70th Secretary of State for about a thousand days.
Before that, I was the Director of the Central Intelligence Agency for approximately a year
Before that, I served in Congress from the Fourth District of Kansas for just
And before that -- that would have begun, I was elected in '10, began
Before that, I was a business person, first running a machine shop in Wichita,
Kansas, that made airplane parts, and then later a similar business that did the same kind
of thing in the energy industry.
Before that time, I was a lawyer practicing law at Williams & Connolly in
Before the 3 years in law school, I served just over 5 years on Active Duty in the
And that takes me back to my college days.
I think I got it all.
I'm sure there were gaps in there for a period of time too
No, you covered what I had on my list.
I want to take you right to January 6th -- or actually just before
January 6th -- Secretary Pompeo, and ask you if you were aware of any advance
discussion before that date about the joint session, about the President's rally at the
Did you have any information in advance of the day that informed your
Do you recall any conversations about the Ellipse rally or the event plans for
I'm going to just intervene there for a moment because we have a
letter from President Trump's counsel asserting executive privilege over any direct
conversations between Secretary Pompeo and the President.
He is, through his lawyer, he's asserting executive
In my judgment, the executive privilege will be respected here as to direct
conversations between the President and Secretary Pompeo.
But, otherwise, we take the position that the waiver by President Biden is
sufficient to permit the Secretary to speak about the conversations he had with other
people outside of the President directly.
So your specific question was directed at conversations with President Trump, and
I'm going to direct Secretary Pompeo not to answer questions about any conversations he
Mr. Burck, let me just clarify.
cover -- potentially cover matters involving official business, but things like campaign or
other matters outside of that the committee's view would be would not be covered by
sort of draw the privilege line.
I mean, I understand the executive privilege would
I just want to be sure I understand going forward where you
Any conversations with President Trump while he was
President that would be in any way related to his official position as President we are
taking the position that we're going to respect the assertion unless a court subsequently
And it sounds like this question about plans for the Ellipse
rally directly with President Trump, in your view, would be in that category?
Although you did ask a broader question, which was did he
have any conversations with anyone, and he said no.
infer from that what you like.
The point is that anything specifically about the President would be
So, you know, you could probably
Secretary Pompeo -- and I appreciate that, Mr. Burck, your clarity
on that up front -- before January 6th, from any source, were you aware of the possibility
of unrest or violence, either at the Capitol, the Ellipse, or anywhere else, attendant to
Did you have any intelligence briefings or information provided to you about
I want to ask you specifically about a meeting that occurred in the Oval
Office on January 3rd, which was the Sunday before.
And this is something that we have
He indicated that there was a meeting that you attended with President Trump,
with General Milley, with Mark Meadows, with several others, that was about Iran.
And I don't want to get into the subject matter of the meeting.
meeting, according to General Milley, there was a brief conversation about January 6th
where the President turned to Acting Secretary of Defense Chris Miller and said -- asked
Do you remember anything at all about that conversation related to January 6th
coming out of that meeting at the White House on January 3rd?
I do recall there being a meeting -- I couldn't tell you if it was
January 3rd or not -- where we were talking about the topic that you described, about
I don't recall other topics other than the topic for which I was present.
Yeah, General Milley just indicated that the President speculated
that there would be a large crowd, fifty or a hundred thousand people, and asked then
Secretary Miller if he had a plan to protect his people.
Do you remember hearing any such conversation?
Just for clarity on the record.
So I will be -- where I understand the
answer to be that the conversation did not occur, I'm not going to instruct him not to
answer any such questions, because I don't think that executive privilege would apply to a
That would be my expectation as
Sounds like, to be clear, Secretary Pompeo, you don't recall any conversation
about January 6th attendant to that January 3rd meeting in the Oval Office about which
Did you listen to the speech, watch it on TV?
My recollection is I first learned about it sometime in the afternoon, I think
I believe I spent most of the day in my office.
You did not attend the rally at which President Trump spoke on the
How did you first learn about violence or unrest at the Capitol?
late afternoon, when my staff asked me to leave a meeting I was in because they wanted
me to come see what was going on.
screens, and saw the violence at the Capitol.
And I went into my office, flipped on the TV
What do you remember, Secretary Pompeo, happening when you turned on
Were people inside the Capitol already?
To the best of my recollection, people, I don't recall if they were
inside, but the pictures were of people that were climbing the walls, climbing the
front -- the facade, it would be the west facade of the Capitol.
have in my mind when I flipped it on.
And that was the first inkling you had that there had been any unrest
Once you learned of it by seeing those images on TV, just sort of walk us
forward about the rest of your afternoon.
I watched it for a while.
I was disturbed that there was
rioting at the Capitol, a place that I had worked for 6 years.
I remember thinking about the Capitol Police, all the work they had done to keep
me safe, keep all my team safe for an awfully long time, wondering how the heck these
folks had managed to get through that.
I'm confident that I went on with the rest of my day.
had things scheduled for the rest of the day, although I don't recall, other than one
meeting that -- I remember the meeting that I was in with a group of pastors who were in
But I don't recall what I did after that.
Did the events at the Capitol require you to take any official action as
Secretary for your workforce or any other professional purpose?
I was very confident that the security teams for both the building at the
State Department, at the HST, the security team for all of my folks would be doing the
right things, that there was no action required.
be attended to in what were the remaining 14, 15 days of our time.
There were lots of things that needed to
Did the violence at the Capitol affect your work at the State Department in any
Did it cause you to alter your schedule or do anything different other
than looking at the television for that period of time?
Not to the best of my knowledge.
At any point during the day, Secretary Pompeo, did you talk to or
attempt to talk to anyone inside the White House?
To the best of my recollection, I don't believe that I did.
recollection that I saw at some point on the TV or read or heard that the Vice President
I had known the Vice President an awfully long time.
being concerned, praying for his safety.
and reach out to him and call him.
I remember at least thinking about should I try
I cannot recall if I reached him or potentially reached his -- one of his team, Marc
Short, who I've known for a long time as well.
spoke with them, or if I just thought about trying to get a hold of them.
Mr. Short indicated in testimony to the committee that you did
Do you recall specifically that conversation, what you said to him or he said to
As you mention it, I do remember trying to reach him, and I may
I'm guessing, but I don't recall the contents of it in particular.
actually speak to him on the evening of or at some point on January 6th.
I can't recall if I actually reached them,
I'm confident what I would have said is, "Are you all
Is there anything I can do to help?"
It would have been a short conversation,
He said that you had called to
make sure that the Vice President was okay, was just checking in.
you also told him that you were talking to other Cabinet Secretaries at the time, that you
had been in touch with colleagues of yours on the Cabinet that night on January 6th.
Does that ring a bell to you?
Cabinet on the night of January 6th?
Were you in touch with other members of the
The only conversation I had with any other Cabinet members on the night of
January 6th that I recall was with Secretary Mnuchin.
Tell us about that conversation, you and Secretary Mnuchin.
My recollection, it was relatively late in the evening.
traveling, I think, in the Middle East.
I received a call that Secretary Mnuchin wanted to speak with me.
me to give him an update, what I knew, what I'd learned, what I'd seen about that day.
If it would have been the Middle East, it would have
He was clearly very upset by what he had seen.
And that was the scope of the conversation as best I can recall it.
Did he say, Secretary Pompeo, why he called you as opposed to someone in
the White House or someone who had more direct knowledge of those events?
Was there any discussion about how he or you should react to the
I don't recall specifically, but we both felt compelled to make a statement.
I think subsequently we both did make statements.
correctly, our view of what we had seen was the same -- that the rioting at the Capitol
was terrible, it was tragic, and we were saddened by it.
And if I recall the conversation
But if I recall, just to finish that up, if I recall my statement that evening -- or
maybe it was the next morning, I can't recall -- that I put out via either the State
Department press team or my Twitter account was something to that same effect.
You did put out a brief statement.
But I'm wondering, was there any discussion with Secretary Mnuchin about
resignations, either yours or other members of the Cabinet?
night about whether it was an issue that you should consider or think about?
And, again, anything more specific beyond issuing a statement
that you talked about in terms of appropriate response with Secretary Mnuchin?
Tim, not that I can recall.
Let me go back, though, to why did you not call anyone inside the
You had a close relationship with the chief of staff and others.
Tell me more what informed your decision not to reach out to them.
As Secretary of State, I had lots of work to do.
subject matter expertise nor, for that matter, any responsibility for security at the Capitol
There was plenty for me to attend to.
You did decide to reach out to the Vice President.
instead of the President or anyone close to him in the White House?
I called the Vice President because I saw he was in a position where he might
have been at risk and wanted to make sure he was okay.
addition to the Vice President of the United States.
And he is a longtime friend in
How about other Members of Congress, former colleagues or contacts of
yours who were, much like the Vice President, in the building that was under attack?
Did you make any attempt to contact any Members of Congress on this day?
To the best of my knowledge, I did not.
Anyone else that you recall calling, Mr. Secretary, beyond the Vice
Now, over the course of the day the President issued a number of
Do you remember in real time seeing the tweets that he put forth, any statements
that he made at the time that he made those statements?
Do you remember seeing the President's very first tweet that afternoon was
about Mike Pence not having the courage to do what should have been done to protect
President's critical tweet about the Vice President that afternoon?
Do you remember seeing or hearing about the
He had a couple of subsequent tweets about supporting Capitol
Police and law enforcement and encouraging people to stay peaceful.
Do you remember knowing about them at the time or thinking whether they were
And then the President finally put out a video statement from the Rose
Garden a little after 4 in the afternoon where he talked about the election being stolen
and knowing the pain of the rioters, but telling them:
You have to go home now.
Do you remember seeing that video statement and having any reaction to it?
I don't recall, although the video statement I did see some time that day.
don't know if -- I don't recall if I actually saw it live or if I saw pieces of it that were being
But I do have a recollection of seeing the President make remarks, I think it
And when you saw that, whenever it was, tell me what your
Did you think it was appropriate?
to send as the riot was unfolding at the Capitol?
Did you think it was the right message
You know, I was focused on a lot of things that day.
moving, and we had a lot of work to do at the State Department.
I don't -- I didn't have an independent set of knowledge, other than what was on
the TV screen, about what was taking place there.
when the President made those remarks.
I don't recall what I was thinking
I'm sure I had a view, just as we racked everything, but I don't recall what my
And I guess what I'm asking, to be clear, Mr. Secretary, is not so
much what was your view then -- I understand it was a busy day -- what your view is now
Was that the appropriate message to send at 4:17 the afternoon as the
I don't have any -- I mean, I'll leave that to others.
Did you reach out to any counterparts in other countries that day to convey
any information or reassure them as the attack on the Capitol was unfolding?
Your statement, Secretary Pompeo, was issued at 6:16 p.m., and it
was in the form of a tweet.
I've traveled to many countries and always support the right of every human being to
protest peacefully for their beliefs and their causes."
It said, "The storming of the U.S. Capitol today is
Lawlessness and rioting here or around the world is always unacceptable.
You then followed it up just seconds later with, "But violence, putting at risk the
safety of others, including those tasked with providing security for all of us, is intolerable,
Let us swiftly bring justice to the criminals who engaged in
Tell us what prompted you to issue those two successive tweets at 6:16 on
I don't recall anything specifically, if someone from my team or someplace
else had helped draft that or write it so there might be a record of that.
have prompted it would have been what I had described to you, was the fact that I had
seen them on TV, on my TV screen that day.
Why in particular, Mr. Secretary, did you make a reference to swiftly
bringing justice to the criminals who engaged in the riot?
This -- your message was issued just 15 minutes after the President's
happen when a sacred landslide election victory is so unceremoniously and viciously
stripped away from great patriots who have been badly and unfairly treated for so long.
Go home with love and in peace.
and message than your tweets 15 minutes later.
And his last tweet was, "These are the things and events that
Was your message in part meant to be a reaction to or purposely different from
the President's message just 15 minutes before?
Was it connected in any way to the President's own prior statements?
Do you know whether or not your message was informed by anyone at the
Did you run it by or get advice from anyone inside the White House
I don't recall, but I don't believe so.
Was it your practice to clear things with the White House before you issue
It depended on the topic, situation.
were other times we -- I would put out statements that had not been fully cleared.
Let me stop there and see if Ms. Cheney or
Ms. Lofgren or Mrs. Murphy, if any of you have questions about January 6th in particular.
I don't have any questions, Tim.
We often did clear things, but there
. o r - do you guys have anything?
Did you, Secretary Pompeo, consider resigning on or after January 6th
Did you talk to any other colleagues of yours in the Cabinet who did resign,
I don't believe that I did.
I don't recall conversations with either Secretary
former Chief of Staff Mulvaney, who was appointed by the President but worked for me.
Tell us about the conversation you had with Mr. Mulvaney on the
I can't recall --was it the night of the 6th?
The only conversation I recall about resignations was from
You all would have the record.
I would have thought it was the next day, but I could be wrong.
I believe he testified it was that night, it was later the night of
January 6th, after order had been restored at the Capitol.
Regardless, what do you remember about the talk with him?
Almost nothing, other than he was distraught.
day and he could no longer serve in the administration.
He said he couldn't take it
He just -- he couldn't abide what had happened that
Did you try to talk him out of it or give him any advice about what he should
Did you have any similar concerns, Secretary Pompeo, about not being able
to abide what had occurred and needing to step away?
Did that cross your mind at all?
As I said before, I thought the rioting at the Capitol was terrible, it was tragic.
Did you have any conversations with others who didn't resign but
thought about it, other members of the Cabinet or other officials?
Not that I recall, other than a conversation that I believe was the day
following, on what would have been the 7th, with Secretary Scalia.
Tell us about the conversation with Secretary Scalia.
I don't recall for sure if Secretary Scalia told me he was thinking about resigning.
So I want to make sure that the record reflects I have no recollection that he said that.
And, again, let me just try and make sure I'm clear on that.
But Secretary Scalia had asked to call me.
That was unusual because we weren't
I was in the national security space.
He wanted to talk about what
And his request of me was, would I be willing to support or participate in a Cabinet
meeting with the President of the United States?
I told him I didn't think that that was a
Tell us more why you thought it was not productive?
And I think I -- I don't recall exactly -- but I think I explained to him what my
thinking -- what I believed my thinking was, was that the President of the United States
was unlikely to resign and so what we should focus on is making sure that we successfully
delivered for America, just as we had for the first 4 years, for the final 2 weeks.
there was an awful lot of work to do, there was transition work that was not yet
complete, and that should be the thing that each of us as Cabinet Secretaries should
spend our time thinking about and working on.
Secretary Scalia testified a little bit about the same conversation.
that your advice to him was that a meeting, a Cabinet meeting, could backfire because it
could anger the President and result in him taking some improper action, one that would
not occur if we didn't go down that road.
Does that sound consistent with your recollection of the conversation with
It doesn't sound consistent with my recollection.
is a fine line -- I remember thinking that it would not be productive.
thinking that I had concerns that it would spur some action that would be -- I'm not sure
Secretary Scalia also indicated, just as you did, Secretary Pompeo, that there was
discussion about the possibility of the President resigning, to which you responded
sarcastically, "Can you imagine how that conversation will go?"
Essentially the President -- suggesting to the President that he resign, your
sarcastic response was skeptical that that would work.
memory of the conversation with Scalia?
Save for the descriptor, I am -- my recollection is I would have said to him
that I thought the likelihood of President Trump resigning was very low.
Secretary Scalia also indicated that Secretary Azar reported that he
had had a conversation with you about this same idea, the possibility of a Cabinet
Do you recall talking to Secretary Azar about the Scalia idea of convening a
Anything else about the conversation with Scalia that you recall,
whether it was the 7th or whenever it occurred?
The only thing is I have some recollection that I said to Secretary
Scalia, "Look, if you think it's important, you should proceed.
President, just as each Cabinet member has the duty to do if we think it's important."
remember some conversation along that line.
And do you know whether or not he followed through and actually
proposed a Cabinet meeting to the President or the chief of staff?
I only know what I've read in public, that he did go see the President.
And I appreciate that distinction, Secretary Pompeo.
looking for is your firsthand knowledge of stuff, not what you've read about in the
newspaper, and your care to distinguish that I appreciate.
There was a man named Christopher Ford, who was an assistant secretary in the
It was actually on January the 8th, expediting his
resignation to be effective because of -- immediately because of January 6th, and he sent
you a letter to that effect.
Do you remember any conversation with Assistant Secretary Ford about his
I don't know that there was a conversation.
Do you remember getting a letter from him or the circumstances of his
My recollection is that this was brought to my attention by, I think it was my
But I remember someone on my team informing me that
Assistant Secretary Ford had tendered his resignation as a result of the events of
But you didn't speak to Mr. Ford yourself?
Did you talk to anybody else about resignation -- not yours, but
theirs -- anyone else across the Federal Government?
Both Acting Secretary Wolf and Secretary Azar ended up resigning
Do you remember speaking with either of them about the
Let's talk now about post-January 6th conversations
about the need to ensure an orderly transition.
Were you involved in some discussions with anyone about the last 2 weeks, from
January 6th to January 20th, taking steps to ensure that we landed the plane or that the
With whom did you have discussions about that topic?
There would have been a number of people on my team who were working
both directly and supervising the transition to Secretary Blinken's team.
have been many conversations substantively about how we were conducting that
I'm sure I would have spoken -- I don't have any direct recollection -- I'm sure I
would have spoken with other Cabinet members as they became adjacent to national
were connected to conducting an effective transition.
None of those really connected to January 6th.
And I would have spoken to some of the other members of the national security
team, including Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Milley, about making sure that we
And I want to get to General Milley because he has provided a lot of
But just generally, were there conversations you had with Milley or others that
were more specific to the reaction to January 6th, the significance of January 6th, the
need to do things to essentially ensure that appropriate decisions were made and a
transition -- peaceful transition -- did occur, not the normal transition stuff, but stuff that
was tied to specific concerns generated by January 6th?
I was confident we were -- the task was the same on January 4th as it
was on January 7th, January 5th, January 6th, January 7th:
He indicated that on January 7th that you had one of a series of calls with him and
Well, let's talk about General Milley.
Mark Meadows, that the three of you spoke regularly, but that on January 7th, in
particular, either you, Secretary Pompeo, or Meadows said, "It's just us now," and that,
"It's up to us" -- the three of you, General Milley, Mr. Meadows, and Secretary
Do you recall discussions like that where the three of you believed you had unique
responsibility to "land this thing" after January 6th?
You never used that term or talked about landing the plane, landing this
Oh, goodness, I've probably used that phrase before.
Did you feel yourself, Secretary Pompeo, some kind of obligation to stabilize
decisionmaking to help ensure that nothing else like January 6th occurred after that
before the transition, before the change in administration?
My recollection is that I was just focused on the work that we had.
we still -- there was still lots going on in the world.
of things we needed to close out.
We did lots in the last 2 weeks, lots
No, we -- look, we all know that anytime there are governments transitioning
anywhere in the world that there is always risk in the gap.
gap, the more that risk increases.
The closer you get to that
This is a matter, I think, of historical fact.
And so I was deeply aware, from the day of the election through the day of
January 20th, that we had to make sure and get this right.
And the closer you got to
that, the more the adversaries would think maybe they could do something in the waning
And so I was deeply focused on that the entire time.
Did you have any, though, special concerns about an orderly or peaceful transition
in the last 2 weeks because of the President's statements, the President's actions, what
I was always confident we were going to have an effective transition.
In that same conversation on January 7th, General Milley
indicated that Mr. Meadows shared with both of you that the President was very
emotional and extremely angry and in a dark place.
Do you remember Mr. Meadows describing the President's mood after
Did he ever describe the President's mood in those terms -- emotional,
You know, not that I can recall in the first, but I'm sure that did reflect it.
wanted us to have 4 more years too.
I was not happy about the outcome of the election
I wanted 4 more years to serve.
So we were all dealing with that and all trying to work towards getting the right
outcome so that the next administration could be successful.
Did you have conversations with anyone, Secretary Pompeo, beyond the
normal handing things off to Secretary Blinken and his team, or anyone else about steps
that you needed to take to ensure an orderly transition of power in the wake of the
Did you have any discussions with anyone about President Trump's
decision making, his ability to make good decisions, whether that needed to be managed
or checked in any way after January 6th?
If I had issues that the President needed to
address, I spoke with the President about those substantive foreign policy issues, national
mission and the transition mission, precisely the same.
I would have continued to perform the mission, both the substantive
Did you have any concerns yourself, whether or not you had conversations,
but any concerns yourself about the President's decision making in the last several weeks
I was always confident that I would have sufficient access to the
President to brief him and get the decisionmaking process right.
Let's talk specifically about any conversation you had with anyone
about the possibility of the 25th Amendment.
Do you remember ever talking about that subject with anyone?
I'm sure the words "25th Amendment" came up in some conversation.
have no specific recollection of that.
with anyone that I can recall that was remotely serious.
It's been reported that you asked folks within the State Department for a
legal analysis regarding the process for invoking the 25th Amendment.
Did you ever make that request to lawyers or others on your team about how
does this work, what happens with respect to the 25th Amendment?
But it was never anything that I had a conversation
The way it works is that the Cabinet in a vote can actually seek to
invoke it if there's concern about the stability or health of the President.
Did you have any discussions about that topic with other members of the Cabinet?
At any -- I have no recollection.
Had someone raised it with me, I
would have dismissed it as preposterous, just fanciful.
Secretary Mnuchin indicated that he had at least one conversation
with you after January 6th about the possible application of the 25th Amendment.
Do you remember talking to Secretary Mnuchin about that?
General Milley similarly indicated that he recalls a conversation with
